questions.question: 1. Consider the linear transformation \( T:\mathbb{R}^2 ightarrow \mathbb{R}^2 \) defined by \( T(x, y)=(x, 0) \), where \( x, y \in \mathbb{R} \). Then the range of \( T \) is
2. Consider the linear transformation \( T:\mathbb{R}^3 ightarrow \mathbb{R}^2 \) defined by \( T(x, y, z)=(x, y+z) \), where \( x, y, z \in \mathbb{R} \). Then the range of \( T \) is
3. Consider the linear transformation \( T:\mathbb{R}^2 ightarrow \mathbb{R}^2 \) defined by \( T(x, y)=(x, -y) \), where \( x, y \in \mathbb{R} \). Then

answers.b: T is onto, but not one-to-one
answers.c: T is neither one-to-one nor onto

questions.question: 4. Consider the linear transformation \( T:\mathbb{R}^3 ightarrow \mathbb{R}^2 \) defined by \( T(x, y, z)=(x+y+z, 0) \), where \( x, y, z \in \mathbb{R} \). Then

6. Consider the map \( T:\mathbb{R}^2 ightarrow \mathbb{R}^2 \) and \( S:\mathbb{R}^2 ightarrow \mathbb{R}^2 \) such that \( T(2, 1)=(1, 1) \), \( T(1, 2)=(1, 1) \), \( S(4, 2)=(3, 3) \) and \( S(8, 4)=(5, 6) \). Let the statements A and B be as given below:
A: \( T \) is one-to-one.
B: \( S \) is not linear.
Then which of the following holds

answers.a: A is true, B is false
answers.b: A is false, B is true
answers.c: A is true, B is true
answers.d: A is false, B is false
